Award.AwardTitle: NSF Convergence Accelerator - Track C: SQAI: Scalable Quantum Artificial Intelligence for Discovery
Award.AbstractNarration: The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports use-inspired, team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and will produce deliverables of value to society in the near future. This grant will benefit society by compressing the pharmaceutical discovery timeline and reducing cost. This would have societal impacts both economically and in human health. A new branch of artificial intelligence, Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN), shows promise for exploring a large chemical space and generating novel pharmaceutical candidates targeted for a certain disease. Quantum GAN (QGAN) has emerged as a path to accelerate classical GANs. This project will create an experimental quantum GAN framework to explore chemical compounds on Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) computers. This will yield a new discovery-based framework, Scalable Quantum Artificial Intelligence (SQAI) which could be employed for other applications.<br/><br/>This Convergence Accelerator team will answer fundamental questions in the context of drug discovery such as: (i) How to exploit quantum advantage to the fullest for drug discovery using NISQ-era computers? Should we use quantum resources for search, discrimination and reinforcement of reward or allocate them fully for search and rely on classical paradigm for regular tasks? (ii) Does a particular molecular representation benefit NISQ-era computers? (iii) Can we enhance the quantum ansatz in QGAN to explore pharmacologically relevant areas of chemical space? (iv) What is the implication of noise on QGAN during training and generation? (v) Are there other material systems that will provide noise immunity to the existing noise-prone qubits? (vi) What kind of flexibility can we offer to the users in exploring quantum computing for their discovery application? The main tasks are focused on developing a software toolchain to bridge the gap between quantum AI algorithms and hardware, exploring drug discovery using NISQ computers, and preparing a quantum smart and diverse workforce. Outreach to K-12 teachers will include a professional development workshop and curricular materials related to introductory quantum computing content.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to create a Scalable Quantum Artificial Intelligence (SQAI) framework to accelerate computational drug discovery and prepare a trained workforce at the intersection of quantum computing, artificial intelligence and drug discovery. Towards this end, we converged an interdisciplinary team of experts from computer science, electrical engineering, physics, pharmacology and education and partners from academia, industry and national labs. We interviewed users from quantum computing and pharmacy domain and experts from academia, industry, government and national labs. We developed various quantum machine learning models such as quantum generative adversarial network (QGAN) and quantum variational autoencoder (QVAE) and trained them using publicly available dataset such as QM7/QM9 and ZINC. Our approach was thoroughly benchmarked with classical machine learning models with respect to training time, number of parameters and quality of generated drug candidates. Since NISQ-era computers suffer from noise that can present various practical challenges during training, we developed various noise tolerant approaches such as compaction of quantum neural network. Our approach was refined over the course of Phase-1 project to align with the user needs and feedback received from the experts.  

On the broader impact side, we developed a prototype series of quantum computing for drug discovery learning activities for middle school teachers and their students. The unit leveraged cloud-based quantum computing and addressed learning goals in mathematics, physical and life sciences, and computer science, with a robust conceptual introduction to quantum computing. This project led to training of 20+ PhD students (including several female), 2 master’s students and 2 Honors students from Penn State Schreyer Honors College. The outcomes were published in 20+ IEEE/ACM or equivalent conference and journal venues and resulted in several invention disclosures. The PIs also educated the community about quantum computing and drug discovery by organizing tutorials, short courses and special sessions in IEEE Design Automation Conference, IEEE Design Automation and Test in Europe Conference, IEEE International Conference on Computer-Aided Design and IEEE International Test Conference, to name a few, serving on panels and delivering invited lectures in various conferences and ACM Student Chapters.

The students working on this project received Nirmal Bose Outstanding Dissertation Award from Electrical Engineering Department at Penn State in 2019, TTTC Edward J. McClusky Outstanding Dissertation Award in 2020 and Penn State Alumni Society Outstanding Dissertation Award in 2022.


Last Modified: 09/25/2023
Modified by: Swaroop Ghosh
